title: Cartesian Product
course: Discrete Mathematics by Prof Sudarshan Iyengar

transcript.text: Let's take a set A of some five elements and then  I write down A in two columns, as you can see, and
then I will try to pick all possible two-element  sets from A. How do I do that? I take something
from the left side something from right side. How  can I do this? I can take A and an A, A and a B,
A and a C, A and a D, A and an E; or B and an  A, B and a B, B and a C, so on and so forth. Do
you see how many possible such two tuples I can  take? It's called the two tuples. I can actually
take 5 into 5, 25 of them. This is called the  cross product of a set A with itself. We denote
that by A cross A. Note this. Throughout this  chapter, this notation will be excessively used.
